Persuadee: I do enjoy donating to charities.
Persuadee: I don't usually have a ton of extra money so it's not an every month kind of thing for me but I try to give at least once a year.
Persuadee: And when I can't give monetarily donate food, my time, and go to blood drives on my university
Persuader: Aww, that's really considerate of you.
Persuader: I have two sponsored kids myself, one from Ghana and one from Mexico and they send me letters every month.
Persuader: Cassidy, you'd be surprised how emotionally attached I am to them and I have never even met them.
Persuader: I send them 20 dollars on their birthdays and then they send me pics of what they bought.
Persuader: It's really sweet.
Persuader: Then there is another charity I like a lot which allows for really small donations.
Persuader: Have you heard of Save the Children?
Persuadee: No, I haven't heard of Save the Children.

Persuader: I like Save the Children because they rank towards the top of reputable charities on the ranking sites.
Persuader: The other thing is that they allow for small donations which have a big impact in countries like Syria where the local currency has dropped so considerably.
Persuader: It's really really sad what's going on over there.
Persuader: Anyways, even 50 cents goes a long way you know?
Persuadee: Yeah, 50 cents isn't too bad.

Persuader: Did you know that there is an option to do that for this HIT?
Persuadee: No, I didn't know but thank you for telling me!
Persuadee: I think I might donate mine too!
Persuader: I say we do it together!
Persuader: See, Cassidy, no single one of us can fix all the problems in this world.
Persuader: There is too much suffering, too many children growing up in poverty and trauma.
Persuader: But together, if we stick together, if we put our money together, you'd be surprised how much we can change in this world.
Persuader: How many lives we can help. , [Summary: The conversation begins with a friendly exchange of greetings and personal introductions, establishing a rapport between the speakers. Persuadee: All I can afford is $5.00.

Persuader: For example,millions of Syrian children have grown up facing the daily threat of violence.

Persuadee: I sponsor a poor child in India every month for $40.
Persuadee: I wish I could help all the children in the world.
Persuader: I would like to personally thank you for that.
Persuader: It is very thoughtful to donate to causes that benefit disadvantaged children.
Persuader: Your donation means a lot to that child in India
Persuadee: It is the least I can do for him.
Persuadee: Most people take for granted what they have in their lives, while there are so many thousands who do not even have the basic necessities.
Persuadee: Imagine not have clean water to drink.
Persuader: I cannot even begin to imagine that and clean water should be a basic right to every child on this planet.
Persuadee: I agree.
Persuadee: There is so much wasted in the world.
Persuadee: I know it is possible for everyone to have enough food and water.
Persuadee: If only the governments and politicians of the world would stop fighting and actually work toward that goal.
Persuader: Yes I agree.

Persuadee: And they let you know what type of progress is occuring both with your child and the community in general.
Persuadee: It is so satisfying to know you are making a real difference in someone's life, and maybe in many lives.
Persuader: I cannot thank you enough for that.

Persuadee: Well it's $39 a month, so $468 annually.
Persuadee: I also send him little care packages every so often.

Persuadee: That will have such a big impact on their lives. , [Summary: The conversation begins with a straightforward inquiry about donating to a charity, with the respondent expressing willingness but financial limitations. Persuader: Have you donated to a charity before?
Persuadee: Yes, I usually donate to soldiers or veteran related charities such as Wounded Warrior Project.
Persuader: Those are great causes also.
Persuader: You mentioned earlier that you believe children to be one of the world's most important assets.
Persuader: Would you be willing to donate your earnings from this task to Save the Children?
Persuadee: I would if I had a specific break down or list of what programs the donations support.

Persuadee: I already checked their website.
Persuadee: Health and education both are important factors

Conversation:
Persuader: Save the Children is a great organization that looks out for the well being of children in need.
Persuader: Currently they are looking for individuals to help their cause.
Persuadee: where is this organization based?
Persuadee: Do they help children from a particular country or is it all around the world?
Persuader: They help children mostly in developing countries around the world.
Persuader: Think about all the stories you hear in the news and on social media about children that need help or have been taken advantage of.
Persuadee: Yeah stories like that are very heart breaking.
Persuadee: What types of programs do they offer?
Persuadee: Like do they just supply food?
Persuader: They often protect children from being victims of hunger, violence, and child labor.
Persuader: They also advocate for schooling and provide opportunities for families to get ahead.
Persuader: It is a great social cause that is worth donating to!
Persuadee: That sound great but you know my biggest concern with making donations to charities is always the question of just how much of the money I give actually reaches to the intended people.
Persuader: Save the Children is a very well known, credible organization with transparency.
Persuader: Visiting the organization's website allows you to understand how even a small donation can have an impact.
Persuadee: Oh I see so they have a website that I could learn more about them.
Persuader: Think about how much money you spend on non essentials in your life.
Persuader: Now think about sacrificing just one of those to help out a child.
Persuadee: Yeah I think its good to help any little bit you can.
Persuadee: How much is the typical donation amount usually?
Persuader: It all depends on what you are comfortable with.
Persuader: Every bit helps.
Persuader: But one thing is for certain, you will feel good about your donation!
Persuadee: So after making a donation, I won't exactly see how the money I give will be used right?
Persuadee: I mean this is not like sponsoring a child or family situation right?
Persuader: You will not see how it directly impacts one child, but instead think about focusing on how your donation would impact multiple children and families!
Persuadee: Yes that is true.
Persuadee: Have you made a donation to this organization before?
Persuader: I try to donate a couple of times per year, especially around the holidays.
Persuader: I have felt great in the past about this and will continue in the future.
Persuader: You will instantly feel better about your decision once you do. , [Summary: The conversation begins with ER expressing enthusiasm for a charitable organization, aiming to inform and persuade EE to consider supporting it. EE's inquiries reflect curiosity and some skepticism, particularly regarding the organization's global reach and financial transparency. ER consistently reassures EE, emphasizing the organization's credibility and the positive impact of donations. EE gradually becomes more receptive, expressing a willingness to contribute, while ER maintains a supportive and encouraging tone throughout, sharing personal experiences to bolster their persuasive efforts.]<|eot_id|>

Persuadee: That sounds like a very nice cause.
Persuader: Yes, it\'s a great cause.
Persuader: And the charity is highly rated with many positive rewards.
Persuader: Including an "A" rating from the American Institute of Philanthropy.
Persuadee: That's awesome!

Persuader: It was founded way back on April 15, 1919!
Persuader: A charity with that kind of history shows that it has made an amazing impact.

Persuadee: That is very impressive.
Persuadee: Do you know on average how much money the charity makes per year?
Persuader: The total operating revenue was $807,412 in 2017, and 9 out of every 10  dollars they make goes straight into the programs and services to help children and families in need.
Persuadee: That is awesome.
Persuader: I know I was surprised by those numbers.
Persuader: A lot of widely known charities aren't as open and honest about where their finances go, but you can easily find Save the Children's financial reports online.
Persuader: That's important to me in a charity.
Persuadee: Yes, definitely.
Persuadee: Unfortunately some "charities" are just scams that do not donate to a worthy cause at all.
Persuader: That's the truth.
Persuader: That's why it's so important to do research before donating.
Persuader: Save the Children even breaks down where exactly your money goes on their website.
Persuader: For example, 34% of the money donated goes to health & nutrition services and programs, 21% to education, 11% to emergencies, 11% to HIV/AIDs, etc.
Persuader: It is fully listed on the site with an easy to read graphic.
Persuader: Super helpful.
Persuadee: That's very helpful.
Persuadee: It is best to be transparent when running a charity like that, especially when the charity brings in a large amount of money.
Persuadee: That way nobody can question anything.
Persuader: Oh yeah.
Persuader: When I first heard about these super well known organizations only actually using about 5% of their proceeds for their services I was shocked.
Persuader: Save the Children uses a total of 86% of proceeds for their services and programs!
Persuader: The rest goes to "fundraising, management, and general" as the website says.
Persuader: That\'s good to hear that it\'s not all about filling some people\'s pockets.
Persuadee: Right.
Persuadee: I understand that people have to get paid for what they do, but they shouldn't be making an extravagant amount of money.
Persuader: Exactly.
Persuader: It's pretty infuriating to know that some people play on people's sensitivities and vulnerable states to just get rich.
Persuader: I know when I make donations I always be sure to get the facts first now.
